item.title: Welcome!
item.dc:creator: me
item.content:encoded: Hello there :). My name is David Barton and I am a software designer and developer. I have been working professionally in software for around fifteen years, designing and developing J2EE enterprise applications built on Oracle databases. I recently had some time on my hands, so thought I would learn a little about iOS and see what all the fuss is about! This blog details my solutions for the assignments, given as part of the highly recommended Stanford University Fall 2011 CS193p lectures taught by Paul Hegarty and available through iTunes U. Enjoy and good luck!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Looking good Mr B, welcome to the real world :-)

Thanks David. I think that I can speak for all iOS dev newbies, in thanking you for helping the community.
Please, please, please keep up the good work.

Just want to say REALLY appreciate what you've done here! I'm taking the iTunes U class and feel like I walked off a cliff after the first assignment.
This is a huge help for my understanding. Much appreciation sir

i4-apps is the response to my pride.
I am working by myself on standford iOS programming course, and your post is really helpful
Thanks !!!

Thank you very much,i did assignment 1 by my self and was hard for me to do assignment 2 and i was searching for a solution-explanation to study and understand.
you were very helpful thanks again

Thanks for sharing with your code and experience. Your codes are pretty neat, good work! I am a new comer to ios, actually to programming, I found I was using too many lines to achieve the same tasks compared to yours. I am still doning the 2010 fall assigement, kind of similar, will come back in short frequence to check your update.:)
Very nice style and excellent written content, practically nothing else we need :D.

Hi David,
just wanted to thank you for sharing your solutions to the assignments here. Great work and very well structured/documented.
I also had some problems, mainly getting a starting point to the assignment 2 tasks. Your coding along with the comments and explanations helped me a lot to proceed. After I got the general idea from your solution I was able to proceed with the majority of the subtasks myself. :)
Thanks again and best regards, Dominik
Just wanted to add a huge "Thank You!", your help is very well received and helps me tremedously. I also follow the iTunesU course and I can't believe how clear and useful is. Thank you again!
Just wanted to say thank you for the resource! It is very helpful.
Your blog is the perfect complement for the Stanford's CS193p Thanks for sharing your knowledge with us.

item.title: Assignment 1: required tasks
item.dc:creator: me

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
It looks like with your additional clause, if the user put it say "enter;5;enter" it would show a calculation of "5", instead of "0 5". Is that right or is there another aspect you are thinking of? The first zero doesn't seem too bad to me, as the user has explicitly pushed it on the stack by pressing the enter key initially.
There does seem to be a problem with the original display field though, in that the user can push 0 multiple times and then multiple zeros will be shown…..
Sí, Math.h is imported as part of Foundation.h.
thanks :-)

Hi David! I have found an issue (99% probably me!) on the pointPressed method, if you add it to the walkthrough as the inmediate task to accomplish, you can enter no zero decimal point numbers as the 1st operand, but when you enter p.e. .25 as your 2nd or subsequent operand things go wrong as this second operand is being taken (in my example) as 25, as I said, it well might be me.

Hi,
the sin() and cos() functions from math.h use radians, not degrees, so you should make conversion to your values before passing them. I know this as i was getting strange results until i figured that out.
Hi -sounds like a good idea. Do you know what the function is that does this conversion?

Hi .. is there an error message given on the console? On error, normally some kind of stack trace will appear in the console window that gives a pointer…
I don't think any additional is needed in CalcAppDelegate…

I don't know, i just did it in the code as the formula is simple:
double radToDeg = [self popOperandOffProgramStack:stack] * M_PI/180;

Hi David, thanks for your prompt reply. hehe .I went to the log navigator and retrieved this message...
GNU gdb 6.3.50-20050815 (Apple version gdb-1708) (Thu Nov 3 21:59:02 UTC 2011) Copyright 2004 Free Software Foundation, Inc. GDB is free software, covered by the GNU General Public License, and you are welcome to change it and/or distribute copies of it under certain conditions. Type "show copying" to see the conditions. There is absolutely no warranty for GDB. Type "show warranty" for details. This GDB was configured as "x86_64-apple-darwin".sharedlibrary apply-load-rules all Attaching to process 341. Pending breakpoint 1 - ""CalculatorViewController.m":15" resolved Pending breakpoint 2 - ""CalculatorViewController.m":14" resolved 2012-05-10 14:50:09.966 Calculator Ult[341:f803] -[CalculatorViewController clearPressed:]: unrecognized selector sent to instance 0x6a2f200 2012-05-10 14:50:09.993 Calculator Ult[341:f803] *** Terminating app due to uncaught exception 'NSInvalidArgumentException', reason: '-[CalculatorViewController clearPressed:]: unrecognized selector sent to instance 0x6a2f200' *** First throw call stack: (0x13bc052 0x154dd0a 0x13bdced 0x1322f00 0x1322ce2 0x13bdec9 0x165c2 0x1655a 0xbbb76 0xbc03f 0xbb2fe 0x3ba30 0x3bc56 0x22384 0x15aa9 0x12a6fa9 0x13901c5 0x12f5022 0x12f390a 0x12f2db4 0x12f2ccb 0x12a5879 0x12a593e 0x13a9b 0x2768 0x26c5) terminate called throwing an exceptionCurrent language: auto; currently objective-c kill error while killing target (killing anyway): warning: error on line 2184 of "/SourceCache/gdb/gdb-1708/src/gdb/macosx/macosx-nat-inferior.c" in function "void macosx_kill_inferior_safe()": (os/kern) failure (0x5x) quit Program ended with exit code: 0
-------------------------------------------------------------------- this line "error while killing target (killing anyway): " spooks me a little. maybe i did somethng wrong the calculatorbrain.h.I added
-(void)emtpy; for the clear button. Maybe this is not enough to send commands to viewController.m perhaps.
I am so lost, i know this xCode is like telling a story. I do get confused when must i create a new file and where to go to at first...I am still learning hehe.

I think the error looks more complicated than it actually is :-). To me the key line looks to be: Terminating app due to uncaught exception ‘NSInvalidArgumentException’, reason: ‘-[CalculatorViewController clearPressed:]: unrecognized selector sent to instance 0x6a2f200? .. do you have a clearPressed method in CalculatorViewController correctly wired to the Clear button? Also you will need an implementation of the empty method inside calculator brain.m as well as in the header file…..
ah yes… easy enough :-). Thanks!

setting the whole array felt a little "cheeky" to me as well, so I called this method on the NSMutableArray:
[self.operandStack removeAllObjects];
Yes.. saves re-initialisation - much better :-)

Thanks for your reply, Jonathan And, that's how i had my code at the beginning. However, the professor has asked not to use removeAllObjects :-( I guess he wants to see that we understand how to initialize and call a method from the model, and still having the same issue of "No visible @interface ..."
do you have any idea of what i might be doing wrong?
cheers

Following up on my last email, i deleted all the code including button, and started from scratch. It doesn't give me any error now, so there you go. Sometimes we just need to take a step back to move forward :-) Thanks for your help and support.

Hi David! In assignment 1, I found there's little information about M_PI in Xcode Help, how did you find the usage of M_Pi ? It's a pity that your solutions stop being posted after assignment 5. Please do keep going post the rest solutions when you get free. best wishes andyagul
google... Google http://www.google.com...

item.title: Assignment 1: extra credit
item.dc:creator: me

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Ah yes, it does seem unnecessary to declare subtrahend. Actually, the same is probably true for divisor in that we could use (1 / [self popOperand]) * [self popOperand]), instead of declaring up front.
Perhaps there is trade-off in that the reduced code here makes things a little less readable.... although as you say, less code = less chance of bugs...
Hi, pressing +/- button is throwing exception for me :(
What is the error message you are getting?

hi David, thanks a lot for your posts, they are indeed very helpful and inspiring. Do you know of a way to personalize the alt+key character input? That means, if I wanted - for example - that ? would appear out of an Alt+A just like ? appears out of Alt+P. is there a way for defining that?

Ah yes... much better :-)
Thanks!
Sorry, I don't know the answer to this one.
In the lecture, they refer to using the button title as bad design. Why is it bad design and how could you improve it?

Hi nerak , I'm a beginner so maybe my answer will not be the right one , i only tell you my guess. i guess it's because your application could be in several languages. In this particular case , a calculator is not a big problem as the operation signs are international. But imagine if you had a label with for example written "substract" and your application had to be in different languages. you would have to if else for every language. Hope this will help , if it's right lol

item.title: Assignment 2: task1
item.dc:creator: me

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: It seems to me that runProgram should really take the passed stack, and start at the bottom, popping things off and pushing them onto a new stack, which it executes as before. This simulates a user entering the operations and operands.

HI Thanks for explanation, i have a quick question on understanding of the requirements. basically, what is the purpose of the "Test 1", "Test 2", "Test 3" buttons, and how do we supply the the value of the variables x,a,b? basically in the calculator i can enter aa*bb*+sqrt, but how do i supply the values of a,b after i entered in the calculator? this is some what confusing me.
Again, thanks for the detail explation

Hi Mani - thanks for posting. My understanding is that the Test buttons are used as a mechanism by which a user can set values for parameters that are part of a program. This post only covers task 1 of the assignment, which doesn't include that mechanism. Task 2 can be found here, and the bit that does show the mechanism for how the different test values can be supplied (Task 3) can be found here. Hope that helps...

Thanks for your post! It helped answer a lot of my question.
In the for() loop in the runProgram method, could you please elaborate why you test the value as an instance of NSNumber and then setting it to zero?
Cheers

Hi - glad the post helped :-)
Hmm… I'm not entirely sure why I put this in now. I think I thought it might be possible for a user to put non numbers in the variableValues dictionary, and I guess it's providing some protection against that. Now I look at it again, it does seem unnecessary and perhaps undesirable even….
Good enough for me. Thanks again.

Hi,
I was working on this last night. One thing I was wondering about is how the calculatorBrain is supposed to be able to accept and run a stored program, a program being an array or stack of operands and operations.
So let's say we want to perform the following calculation: 2, 3, 4, +, *
If you typed this into the calulator, the follwoing would happen:
2,3,4 get pushed onto the stack. You press +, and runProgram execiutes this and the stack now contains 2, 7 You press * and the stack now contains 14.
But I can't see how you can pass an array containing "2, 3, 4, +, *" to the brain, as runProgram would first try to execute the top operand i.e. "*" and to do this it would take the next two objects off the stack and try to multiply them and to push the result back onto the stack. These 2 objects are "+" and "4" which won't work.
Now the instruction has being doing this a lot longer than I have, as I assume that I'm missing somethings, but I'm not sure what.
Any ideas?

For your example it would work as follows: 1. Pop operand = * 1.1 Pop operand = + 1.1.1 Pop operand = 4 1.1.2 Pop operand = 3 1.2 Pop operand = 2 The key here is that the + operation completes before the * operation does. This is because popOperandOffProgramStack is being run recursively, so the second pop for the * operation happens after the two pops for the + operation….

Thanks David,
Had to think about it for a minute or two but I understand now:
I was thinking "OK - so * has to pop the next two operands off the stack, which are '+' and '4' which it can't multiply", but of course it calls the popOperandOfStack (pOOS) method, which firstly returns a '+', so it then calls pOOS again (twice) which gets '4' & '3' respectively. So when it called pOOS for the first operand of the '*' operation it didn't get '+', it actually got '7'. (Thinking out loud here).
The instructor doesn't go into much detail, leaving you to have to work things through yourself a lot.
Thanks again.
Steve
no problem .. there is a lot of pOOPS going on :-)

Hi,
First of all, thanks for your posts, really helps me with this course.
I have just one question: In the assignment, it was asked that we keep the original runProgram method (the one that takes no dictionary). how do you determine in the controller which runProgram methos to use? In fact, why even use the older version? it seems as though we can just use the newer one (the one with the dictionary) at all times, since it checks for the existense of variables).
Hi - yes it does look like the older runProgram is entirely unnecessary. My controller is calling the new version …. with no need for the older version at all.

Thanks so much for your clarity and generosity. I've been mulling over this for a couple days, and you've enlightened my understanding.
Thanks!
Thanks for saying - glad you have found it useful :-)

I am just a beginner..... i am getting stuck with the method popOperandOffProgramStack. can i implement it in a way similar to method popOperand??
Thanks.
hi - Paul Hegarty shows how to do this in Lecture 4…..

Hi,
First of all, thank you for your walkthrough. I've been having trouble understanding this assignment for the past few days. I've followed and understood all of the your steps until the last part where you have new "Test" button with testPressed action.
I'm wondering why might you do the "Setting up the Brain" that way? From what I understand, you pushed variables a and b twice with operations of *, +, and SQRT. What would happen if you want to do more than those 3 operations or add a third variable?
Thank you again!

The check for NSNumber is to check against someone adding a variable to the program, but not providing a proper value for it in the dictionary.
If the corresponding value is not a number, or if it doesn't exist at all (and would then be nil), then it simply sets it to 0.
Hi Michael - I think you need to initialise the set, otherwise you can't add items to it...
Ha, thanks for noticing that! No wonder I was getting a bug in that code...
I think what going on here is that this is a Test of a particular program. A Unit Test, it is not a general part of the program.

I found this incredibly useful, thank you. With Assignment 2 I think that the difficulty lies in understanding what is required as much as in the coding itself. I am running a record of my own progress and will add a paragraph about exactly what the walk through to recursive program lecture did and what is being asked for in the Task.

I went through what was done in the demo to get to the start of Assignment II. The idea being to help people who (like me) read the Assignment and had difficulty grasping what was required. Hope that people find it helpful, I stuck it in my blog about how I am getting on. It is about half way down with the title CS193p What happened between Assignment 1 Calculator and The Start of Assignment II? http://brianbikezen.blogspot.co.uk/2012/08/objective-c.html

Hi, its very helpful but i dont know why i'm getting some errors like when i call "[self isOperation:obj]" the compiler syas "no known class method for selector "isOperation"" it says same for "popOperand" and for "program" it says, property program does not found on object type CalculatorBrain please reply me ASAP Thanks :)

item.title: Assignment 2: task2
item.dc:creator: me

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Hi David,
Could you please explain the origin of the isValidProgram: method.
Cheers

Hi David,
Could you please explain the origin of the isNoOperandOperation isOnewOperandOperation isTwoOperandOperation ??

David-
It was a relief to see someone working on this course that was actually organized.
I am a bit behind you in the assignments. I got caught cold in assignment 2 with the variables. So I just kept going with the lectures.
I'm assuming that: isNoOperandOperation; isOneOperandOperation; isTwoOperandOperation are class methods that need to be created, but I'm thinking that's overkill in the method department. Wouldn't it be easier to create one class method for one operand (which might be in the code already), and add or subtract from each method call?
but I am still getting my head around how to add variables in the running program.
If I come up with a solution I will post it.
cheers

Thanks for the feedback Seth.
These methods are not explicitly part of the assignment - they are of my own making :-). Unfortunately I left them out of the post by mistake - my assignment 2 implementation of them is as in previous comment….
Be good to know if there is a more efficient way this can be done though - I didn't quite follow what you were saying about using one class method… Would be great to see an alternative solution if you come up with one...
Yes, I'm not sure of an alternate to these methods. I am still trying to debug my Assignment 2 completion. But I will go back and see as this course progresses. Perhaps we could add them to a block.

I haven't quite got to blocks yet in my objective C book… :-). I did revisit these methods as part of performance tuning in assignment 3, so they' re certainly not ideally written in my assignment 2 code.
Good luck with debugging!

I think I follow your approach…. if the expression is for example 5 + 3, does your implementation show 5 + 3 or (5+3) - i.e. with superfluous brackets… I think this is avoided with the de-bracketing approach…

Hey, thanks for the reply! No, it would only show "5+3" (without superfluous brackets). BUT I now see that further down the line it could include some superfluous brackets.. it passed the assignment criteria, but if the calculation gets any longer than the examples given, the chances are it will include some extra brackets.. I think I might change it!

Actually David, can I ask you (if you can be bothered that is!) to tell me what your calculator outputs for the following commands:
6 E 9 E 5 E 9 E 6 + * / /
I'm not entirely sure but I think there may be a small bug..

I actually had a similar problem with the code I uploaded here.. I didn't handle those cases either! A fix like that seems ok, however you should handle the other case too when x needs to be wrapped in brackets.
also, im thinking would there be a problem when you do something like:
4 E 5 E + 3 E 4 E + /
or is it ok?
I've adopted your method (thanks! :D) and used it with the method I have above to (hopefully) handle all cases.. still trying to see if everything is covered lol

I had to make a minor modification to de-bracket , but I think 4 E 5 E + 3 E 4 E + / displays ok as (4+5) / (3+4).
Do you have an example of a case where * causes a problem? Also link for your uploaded code isn't working ...

Hey David, sorry, I wrote my last post in a hurry and it wasn't clear at all.. I didn't mean that I uploaded code - I was referring to the code I posted at the top of this post! Also, with "x" I wasn't referring to multiplication, but to the variable in the code.. i.e. with the fix you handle cases for the y variable
description = [NSString stringWithFormat:@"%@ %@ (%@)", x, topOfStack,[self deBracket:y]];
but perhaps you need to handle the other cases too for x:
description = [NSString stringWithFormat:@"(%@) %@ %@", [self deBracket:x], topOfStack,y];
at least thats what I had to do on my end, I'm not sure if its taken care otherwise in your code. A good way to test might be by trying:
5 E 6 E 9 E // and 5 E 6 / 9 E /
The answer should be different in each case!

Ah.. my mistake. I read your post in too much of a hurry :-).
I think it works for me ok for the two tests, the results I get are: 5 / (6 / (9)) and 5 / (6) / (9)
... seems ok, albeit with some more superfluous brackets (which I can't seem to find an easy way to get rid of!). Something for another day maybe :-)
yeah, its been quite a headache to be honest! Thanks for sharing everything though, its been great reading your blog and discussing different ideas :)

i am kind of stuck here... when you changed the return types of methods popOperandOffStack runProgram to id...how exactly have you modified the performOperation method??? i tried few things but it isn't working...i would appreciate your guidance :)

Thanks for posting this.
I've come up with a really nice solution to the minimal parentheses problem. No extra string searching is required, it always provides the exact result I'm looking for, and it deals with several cases your solution hasn't. It only adds about 2 lines of code per 2-operand-operator. I'd very much like to talk to you about it before I post. If you send me an email, possibly with your phone number we can chat. Thanks
Pete

Hi I've posted my code for minimal parentheses on git:
https://gist.github.com/3166342
It's not an addition to your code, but an entirely different approach that requires no string searching or parentheses REMOVAL. I'd be interested to hear your comments on it.

Hi Pete,
This looks really interesting - I haven't had a chance to go through it properly, but will try to take a good look in the next few days. It certainly seems like a very elegant algorithm - I would like to make sure I fully understand it and will respond as soon as I can.
Just wanted to say, I really like your general coding style - I'll be taking a few tips from it :-)
Thanks for posting.
Yes, works a treat. Excellent stuff!

Thanks for the kind words
I like your coding style too!
If would be fun to talk with you.
I'm a retired developer who's made some hit products. Why not send me an email (possibly with your phone number) so we can talk at length.

Hi David, Thanks for posting your solution with such a nice outline of your process. I was looking at how you returned the topOfStack in descriptionOfTopOfStack and I see that you just did the following... return [topOfStack description]; I imagine that this forces the topOfStack to be an NSString, but I am having trouble finding documentation on how it works. In my program I return with a cast as follows... return (NSString *) topOfStack; It is working the same way, but I can't seem to follow what you are doing with description. I actually tried the same thing and it will only work when I name my variable description. Can you help me understand this? Thank-you for your time!

Hi Megan, topOfStack is either an NSString or an NSNumber. Both NSNumber and NSString inherit from NSObject, which contains the description method. So, there will be an implementation of description in both the NSNumber and NSString classes which returns an NSString and calling [topOfStack description] will call to these implementations.

Hey David, thank you so much for providing such extensive guidance on these assignments. If I were to have taken this as an actually University course, I'm worried that I would have already been kicked off just two assignments in. I'm finding it awfully difficult to wrap my head around.
I'd like to blame this on me being just 19, but I know for a fact there are people far younger and far better at programming than me.
I was curious, what is the name of the Objective-C book that you are currently (or were currently) using. Thank you very much.

Hi James,
I am using Programming in Objective-C by Stephen G. Kochan, which I found quite useful.
I'm not sure how I would have coped if I taken it as an actual University course either. Each assignment took me longer than I would have had time for, if I had done it on Stanford time!
Stick with it :-)
David

Thanks a lot, I think I may buy that book as a bit of extra help. Currently on your next post; 'Assignment 2 Completion'.
Unfortunately I'm having a bit of trouble with the variables. Have you posted your source code anywhere that I could possibly dig up?
Thanks a lot,
James.
HI - The source code for the assignments is all on github, and is linked from the right sidebar on the homepage.

The only comment i have with this solution is if you have recursive call the NSSets that are being created at the beginning of your method will be created for each recursive call which impacts memory usage. Not huge in this case, but something to look out for.
I was wondering how you could create those lists a 'const static' as you would in C++

Oops... missed this post... still how do you do 'const static' in ObjC? My idea for a solution was to declare the list as a property, but i haven't be able to make this work in a class method. The syntax is eluding me at the moment. (or concept ;-) )

First of all, thank you very much for the tips! Extremely helpful. A couple of comments...
I think your update to handle proper bracketing of multi-component divisors unwittingly also brackets a single number. I ended up doing just a simple check to see if the de-bracketed version of y had a length > 1 and if so, bracket it... otherwise no.
Lastly, if you enter 3 E 5 E 2 +, unless I'm not understanding your code correctly would produce a stack description of "5 + 2, 3" whereas I think it should be "3, 5 + 2" no?
Thanks again!

Felipe, that is very nice clean code. I did the same thing as you, but not so pretty. My solution was a bit more general, in that I made an NSDictionary which returns the precedence level (a positive integeer) for any given operation. My equivalent of your +isParenthesesNeededForOperation method does a comparison of precedence levels rather than using nested ifs. This makes the program easy to scale to any number of precedence levels, in case you want to include exponentiation and logical operations.
I wonder if your program handles a RPN stack such as (x a b + -) correctly. Unless I am missing something, I think your program would return x - a + b, when the correct result is x - (a + b). My program does an extra step which encloses operand2 in parenthese in the event that the levels are equal and the current operation is not associative.

item.title: Assignment 2: completion
item.dc:creator: me

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Awesome work! Was just wondering, after you changed your popOperandOffProgramStack to return an id, do you not need to change your performOperation and runProgram methods to return an id as well?

hi mr curious - thanks for the comment.
As you say, you do need to change performOperation and the runProgram methods too, to ensure that they also return id. I forgot to mention that :-)
Great tutorial. Thanks David!!!

When are you calling synchronizeView()? I've read through the progress you've made on both assignment 1 and 2 and I don't see where you created this method, or when you utilize it.
My approach to these assignments has been slightly different than yours in that I refresh the calculator result directly from operationPressed(). I suspect that you are calling synchronizeView from operationPressed().
Excellent breakdown of you solution to the problems within the assignments.

Hi, I am calling synchroniseView() whenever the brain gets updated - I think in operationPressed, clearPressed, variablePressed and enterPressed. I started off doing any updates to the view in the individual methods, but in the end figured it would be better to abstract to a single method and then just call this whenever the view needs to be synchronised with the model …
Were / how did you declare "testVariableValues" I'm trying to use property and synthesize but I'm getting compile error.
Turns out the problem was something else ... I still had a method returning "String" instead of "id". Working now ... great articles, very helpful, keep going.

Thanks David for posting your solutions. Keep up the good work!
It's extremely useful, when I get stuck to take a peek at someone else's solution. It's interesting to see both how you have done something a bit differently to me and where our solutions are similar.
Are you going to continue through to the end of the course?
Thanks, Andy

Thanks Andy - always good to hear that people are finding it useful! Feel free to comment on any differences between our solutions - especially where you prefer your own :-)
Yes, I am hoping to continue through, maybe at a at slower pace though. Will have to see to how things go.

Hey David, I'm taking the class through iTunes U and found your blog incredibly useful. So thanks for your dedication to posting. In the beginning of my synchronize view function, I'm running the program, and the return type of the program is a double. Since I'm storing this into a variable called result (which is type id), I'm getting an error. But I didnt think this would give me an error. Any ideas? id result = [CalculatorBrain runProgram:self.brain.program usingVariables:self.testVariables]; initializing '__Strong id' with an expression of incompatible type 'double'

Hi Jonathan, My implementation for runProgram is returning an id, not a double - so I am not getting the error.As I understand it, the type id can be used to store a pointer to any object. I don't think you can point a variable of type id to a double (or a float, int, char etc...) because these data types are stored as values not pointers to values…..

makes sense. I found out later that more of the code was changed to return IDs rather than dbls. You're right, these last few tasks do require a major code overhaul to complete them. Thanks again for posting this.

Hi David,
I am a beginner in iOS programming. I have the same error because I have two methods called 'runProgram' and both return a double instead of an (id). Could you share your thoughts on this?
Thanks!

Hi, I think that you need to change both the runProgram to return an id instead of a double, and also change the popOperandOffProgramStack method to return an id too… This is because runProgram is calling into popOperandOffProgramStack. Does this resolve the error - if not, what is the error message you are getting?

Your implementation is very close to mine here …. I'm not sure why your getting the error, but it is probably worth using the debugger or putting in a check to see whether or not either stack or theValue are nil when replaceObjectAtIndex runs….

Very good suggestion. I will try that.
Thanks!!!

Hi David, I am trying to fix my code making runProgram return an id, but then I am getting troubles with the function popOperandOffStack. Apparently I can do arithmetic operations with id objects. Do you know how to fix this?

hi Samuel .. you can convert the id to a double value using [operand1 doubleValue] where operand1 is the variable of type id. You can then convert the result of the operation back to NSNumber and return it …
Is your runProgram method returning an id or a double? It needs to return an id
My mistake I forgot to change the declarations in the headers files. Thank you very much David. Really useful your tutorial
I got initializing _strong id with an expression of incompatible type double.
The Extra credit says: "...one way to do this (and to get more experience with using id) might be to have runProgram:usingVaribleValues: in CalculatorBrain return an id (instead of a double)..."

Hi David
Thanks for posting your solution! I also took the same approach as you for assignment 2 task 1 with regards to pushing variables onto the stack, but then had a problem with my understanding of how that method was to be invoked from the controller. I see you've added a new method called variablePressed, which i'm not sure is correct. Aren't you supposed to only push operands onto the stack if Enter is pressed? At the moment you push variables onto the stack in an inconsistent way as to how the operand double values are? I think I'm missing something obvious here! Thanks

The assignment also states the following: "(e.g. you can ignore an attempt to push a variable named “sqrt”)."
To me this would imply that the variables are taken from the display text and not the current title of the new variable buttons. I also understood the variable buttons would just be copies of the existing operand buttons, but labelled appropriately. Argh, my head hurts!

Hi Geoff - Yes it does seem a bit inconsistent. If I remember correctly, I think I pushed variables on to the stack immediately to prevent the user from typing in the variable more than one time before pressing enter (e.g. ab) and then being able to put an unknown string in the program. I'm sure there are multiple ways of solving the problem though!
Hi Alan - On first look, the code seem ok. Nothing obvious. Are there any more details in the error message? - e.g what exact line it is failing on.

hi, I have some questions regarding to part 3(c) In this part, a "synchronizeView" method was written to get the result and update all the display. I would like to ask whether we need to remove the existing [self.brain performOperation:operation] in the method handling the pressing action of operations ? If so, how can we still push the operation (+-*/,...) into the program brain ? As the new "runProgram" only pop the top object in program brain for further operations. Or, am I having some mis-understanding on the question ? Thanks very much for your comment.
Hi TS - No, I haven't removed that call from the operationPressed method. The method pushes the operation to the brain and then calls synchronizeView to update the display.
Much thanks ! I think I've got the ideas now

Hi David,
I followed everything that you said and got the calculator working. However, I am not able to figure out how to convert the variable into double values. For example. if I hit 2 Enter, and hit on x, it shows me x+2 on the display and not the double value of x + 2 on the display ( hence in this case, if default value of x is 0, it should show me 2 on the display but it shows x+2 )
Any ideas on how to fix this ?

Hi,
I really appreciate your work! I just wanted to no if you could post the complete project at this stage, to go on to assignment three.
Chhers
Hi -all of the available source code for both projects is in GitHub - linked on the sidebar on the homepage.

item.title: Assignment 3: required tasks
item.dc:creator: me

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Well I cleared up where I was going wrong. I was trying to rely on an outlet made to my View from My ViewController before I had written the outlet property into the ViewController. I have made a blog summarising what is going on with Protocols and Delegates, so if you get here a bit mystified I have done a simple App to illustrate the points. The blog entry is here. http://brianbikezen.blogspot.co.uk/2012/09/making-ios-app-using-protocols-delegates.html

Hey, I tried your modification if the seque code and ran it with the iPhone simulator. I noticed that I get a nested push animation (my prepareForSegue method gets called twice for some reason) use wanted to know of you came across this as well?
Thanks
Unless did you change anything in your storyboard re: the segue?
Hi - I am not seeing this problem... I put at NSLog in the prepareForSegue method and I am only seeing one call when it segues from the Calculator to the Graph….

I found the problem. I was pushing the segue from the drawGraph button as opposed to the viewController.
Thanks for your help Have a great day
Hi Mani, The height will be less than the width whenever the device is in landscape mode…. I guess it's about calibrating the face size, so that it works well in both orientations

I am trying to understand what origin and scale values will the view have. When you are trying to storeScale and storeAxisOriginX and AxisOriginY in GraphViewController, what kind of values would the CalculatorBrain return? Can you give me an example.
I am having difficulty with the math part about the Graph coordinate values and View coordinate values. If there is a screenshot of the graph drawn, that would be helpful.

Hi there, The origin will have values, representing the coordinates of the graph axis within the view … so anywhere from (0,0) to (x,y); where x is the width of the view and y is the height. The scale starts at 1 and then either increases or decreases depending on whether or not your are zooming in or out … it get's reset back to 1 when the zoom gesture has completed. CalculatorBrain is being used here only to describe the program. I use the resulting NSString as the key against which to store the origin and scale against. The effect I was going for was to allow different graphs to 'remember' their own specific origin and scales. It's my chosen implementation of req #10 based on the guidance of hint #24. I've added a screenshot of the graph view here. Hope this helps :-)
Hey! Will you be posting assignments 4 - 7 anytime soon? Thanks!
Hi … yes I'm planning on posting the required tasks for assignment 4 in the next couple of days. It's been a busy month :-)

Hey,
Thanks for posting your solutions, at least I can now compare what i've been doing with something... :)
Just one small question though, any particular reason you implemented in GraphViewController the instance method - (id) initWithNibName:(NSString *) nibNameOrNil bundle:(NSBundle *) nibBundleOrNil ?
Thanks, D.

Hi,
That method is added by default when the class is created. I think I must have just forgotten to delete it…. :-)

haha ok i see ! ;)
Seems that the method initWithNibName:bundle: is used to directly create controllers using code (and associate them with their corresponding NIB view file) when not using storyboard (i.e. mostly before the version iOS 5 I guess) which seems (in addition to reference counting) to have been be quite a pain ! Therefore, this still might be worth doing it if you want your controllers to be shared and/or developed under previous iOS versions. The lectures only targeting iOS 5, this belongs only to general understanding/knowledge of iPhone development I guess.
Thanks anyway, D.
no storyboard does sound like a pain. Thanks for the info :-)

i m new to iphone development... i have to do this assignment by using SplitViewController for Ipad but i dnt know the steps how should i add SplitViewController in the project?moreOver i have to add Pinch Gesture too. Looking for your Reply Thanks in Advance

hi Ali - the lectures show how to add a SplitViewController and to create the iPad Storyboard - it's lecture 7 that goes through it in detail... I think the pinch gesture is the same as on the iPhone - so no changes there….
My source code is available at https://github.com/i4-apps/Calculator - this shows my Calculator storyboard.
If you have a more specific question, then please let me know and I will try to answer…

Thank you for posting all those assignment solutions. I am just wondering if you know how to simulate triple-tap gesture on iOS iPhone simulator? Or, it can only be tested on a real iPhone?
Thank you !!!
You can just click three times with your mouse… that works for me.

Hi, thanks for posting your nice solutions! I have a question about this method in graphView.m: convertToGraphCoordinateFromViewCoordinate:(CGPoint)coordinate, in this method, how did you determine the graphCoordinate.x = (coordinate.x - self.axisOrigin.x) / self.scale;and graphCoordinate.y = (self.axisOrigin.y - coordinate.y) / self.scale; especially for the y. I mean what's the math behind it? Thank you very much.

Hi,
The purpose of this method is to position a given view coordinate (point) on the graph. The subtraction part of the calculation positions the point relative to the graph's axis (which is in view coordinates), and the second part of the calculation scales the coordinate to convert it into the graph coordinate system. The y calculation looks slightly different to the x calculation, because in view coordinates y=0 is in the top left and increases going downwards, whereas in the graph coordinate system y increases as you go upwards…
To see this better, it may be worth putting some logging in the method to understand what data gets passed in and how it changes as the calculation runs….

Thanks for the solution, I have a question though. In your design (and mine as well), the graph view declares a protocol to be used by the controller. In the class demo, Paul showed the favorite capability using another delegate. As far as I know, there can't be two delegates to one controller, how should this be solved? THANKS!

I'm having trouble with self.title. I can see that it is set in the code but the display doesn't show the updated contents.
Did you create this as a UILabel on the GraphView controller? I put mine there so the graph view could respond to gestures and not affect the title.
Hi - as I understand it, a controller (or any class) can extend only one class, but implement as many protocols as it likes...

Hi,
Title is a property on the underlying UIController class - I didn't create a UILabel ….
It seems to works ok for me. Maybe worth putting in some debugging to make sure that the call to set the title is actually being made?
hello, I'm a students in China, I find your article is very usefull, but I have a question about the #import "AxesDrawer.h", there seem to have no this file,could you show it for me? thanks,
or give me your whole banch of source code, I would very thank you for your help
Thanks Allen - yes my code has the same bug. Thanks for highlighting!
Hi Lin, This file was supplied as part of the Stanford University download. My full source code (which includes this file), can be found here.

Hi Davis, you solutions have been very helpful... i have implemented the drawGraph methd but it isn't draw a graph at all, when i debugged i observed that it calculates value of y only once there after y =0 Any idea why could it happen....
Thanks, PD.
spell mistake, really sorry I meant David

Hi PD,
Just a quick question, have you connected your graphView IBOutlet to the UIView in the storyboard?
I had this issue for a cuople of minutes, because the IBOutlet was declared in the .m file.
PC
Where are you instantiating the graphBounds property?

Hi James,
It's been a while since I looked at this, but I think I ran into some head-scratching moments here too. I think the problem you are having is that the outlets inside the GraphViewController aren't available at the time that prepareForSegue is called - so you can't set them to anything. I think that (self.graphView = nil) at this point - worth checking….
thank you David,you are so handsome!
Thanks again for this site! Why did you set up the method to deliver Graphbounds isntead of just using self.bounds everywhere?

I am completely baffled, I have got your code working but in my version I can't get the datasource delegate to be instantiated, when I try to access the methods, I get no protest or crash, the method just aint implemented or visited, if I put a break in the code and look at the trace, the datsource is there but it is zero?

I've spent hours trying to figure it out.
The only time in my program that refreshGraphProperties is getting called is where I'm calling setProgram from prepareForSegue, and that setProgram is then calling refreshGraphProperties. However, my graphView is never set, and so the function returns early.
After that, nothing happens. My graphView has never been set, and and soo all I see are axes and a straight line.
Where should graphView be being set? I don't understand! I've been killing myself for hours trying to figure it out. My new ViewController is set to GraphViewController, the view inside that is set to GraphView, and I have linked the graphView pointer to that view. SO confused!

hi i'm studying this assignment but i don't understand NSUserDefaults ,particularly, this line of code float scale = [[NSUserDefaults standardUserDefaults] floatForKey:[@"scale." stringByAppendingString:program]];
I looked for in documentation So 1)NSUserDefaults standardUserDefaults return the shared defaults object system of application 2)floatForKey returns the floating-point value associated with the specified key in this case scale
my question is... program is my descriptionProgram, for example sin(x), then @"scale." stringByAppendingString:program] -> scale.sin(x).... I don't understand the meaning of scale.sin(x) associated at floatForKey...why the dot in scale.?I'm so confused :(
can You help me please?
Still haven't figured this out. Any help?

Yeah, thanks man. I did manage to fix it. I still don't know quite what I did, but it was a bug with the storyboard connections. I went into the .xib file and deleted the whole graph view controller, my graphView outlet, and just started again. Something in there seemed to fix it.
The book I'm reading actually recommends against using storyboards because apparently there are a lot of issues with them. I've already ran into a few.

item.title: Assignment 3: extra credit
item.dc:creator: me

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I had originally done something like your operand counts dictionary, so what was slow for me was the drawing, actually... and i haven't really addressed that part of the assignment yet... incidentally i'm wondering if drawing arcs for each pixel isn't quite time consuming compared to some other operation that might be easier... unless arcs are drawn with bill atkinson's variation on that bresenham algorthm, where it's all done using only i think addition...

Yes, it does look like drawing arcs is relatively time consuming. I've replaced the Arc drawing with this: CGContextAddLineToPoint(context, coordinate.x - 1/self.contentScaleFactor, coordinate.y - 1/self.contentScaleFactor); … and performance is now comparable in both modes. Thanks for highlighting that.

I took a completely different approach. Since pixels are just rectangles I did this instead:
CGContextFillRect(context, CGRectMake(coordinate.x, coordinate.y - increment, increment, increment));

David,
First off, I just wanted to say thanks for such a great tutorial/walkthrough. It was the very thing that I was looking for and you explained everything very well. I just downloaded your source code and the iPhone portion doesn't show the graph. I think everything was hooked up correctly, did I forget to do something? Thanks once again for all the great work you have on this site!

Hi David, Thanks a lot for publishing your answers. They often times came out very handy! Quick question: Where do you define OPERAND_COUNTS? Is it a property of the class? If so, how can it be accessed from a class method? Thanks!
hi Douglas - I'm not sure what is wrong exactly. Seems to work of for me...
Hi Osekkat, I have defined it as the first line under the @implementation of CalculatorBrain static NSDictionary *OPERAND_COUNTS; Not sure if this right, or whether there is a better way.
Thanks for the reply David, I will try it again.

Oh ok, I didn't realize it was a static property. Makes sense.
Thanks.

Hi David, I finished assignment # 3.. but all functionalities work fine with iPhone, but when i make it universal it doesn't even show the master view(left side) of the splitViewController. Do i to make any changes in the code when we make the app universal. I did everything as told by Paul in lecture 7. But still its nt working . Can you suggest any changes.
Thnaks.

item.title: SplitViewController Popovers
item.dc:creator: me

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Hmmm, seems like a bug doesn't it... the storyboard editor has a tick box to define an explicit size for the popover but it doesn't have any effect. Neither does changing the self.contentSizeForViewInPopover line in the MasterViewController'sawakeFromNib method. You'd think that changing either of these would make the popover revert to the old form in a bubble style, but it doesn't.
Seems silly of Apple to have left both these customisation points in - one in Xcode and one in the generated source - if neither have any effect. Probably worth filing a bug report.

Certainly does…. I've seen a few posts complaining about it and there seems to be a bit of activity on the Apple forums. Using presentPopoverFromBarButtonItem can be used to override the new behaviour but I couldn't get it to dismiss properly…. I think the size setting customisations would still be relevant for manually created popovers, as opposed to the popover that comes as part of the SplitViewController implementation...

I tried to do something similar using the UIPopoverController that is part of the splitViewController:willHideViewController:withBarButtonItem:forPopoverController . The problem I kept getting is that if I make the popover appear in landscape then turn the device, the popover doesn't seem to disappear cleanly. I tried your way of instantiating the popover, but seem to get the same problem … seems like a bug to me… as the two line method is much much cleaner :-)

Hi Phillip - a fellow Bathonian .. heh - what are the odds :-)
Which version of iOS are you using? It looks like the lectures are using iOS 5.0 - I think the problem was introduced in 5.1...

Hey,
Thanks for the heads up. Yes, I have been coding for iOS 5.0... D'oh!
Cheers
Phil
Nice read, I just passed this onto a friend who was doing a little research on that. And he actually bought me lunch as I found it for him smile Thus let me rephrase that: Thanks for lunch!

In my version of xCode I have a choice between iPad 5.0 Simulation and iPad 5.1 Simulation. In 5.0 the popover works just fine, in 5.1 it is the sliding splitview look. This is actually quite annoying, because it makes panning the graph not function very well. The iOS input keeps trying to slide the calculator open if I try to start my panning from the left side of the graph.
You can turn the 'presentsWithGesture' property off (set to NO) on the popover controller. That will stop it from sliding in from the left so your panning will work normally again.
hi Tycho, can you please elobrate on that? i am a novice and i have 5.1 simulator. How do i edit the code to make it look like whats showin the demo
what is my popover controller?
It Works ! Thank you.

hi david
i'm a Your italian follower and i'm learning to use objective -c with xcode since few months..... I saw the lesson 7 from cs193p and i have the same problem with UISplitViewController in iOS 5.1.... now i don't understand the first and third steps with crtl + drag because my storyboard doesn't show the masterViewController but only detailViewController....I ask You a BIG favor, can You have a source code of lesson 7 modified by you for iOS 5.1 please?
thanks for Your patience

item.dc:creator: me

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi .. Yes - the subtitles are appearing for me. There seems to be a lot of photos where there was no description._content … for me I am setting and empty subtitle in these cases...

By the way, I didnt see your implementation to set the network activity indicator on. I failed to do that by just setting the property networkActivityIndicator... Of [UIApplication sharedApplication] to YES and NO. Can U explain the mechanism a little bit?
Hi - I think this is described in the latest post - Assignment 5: tasks 1-2

Thanks :-)
My method is called setupModel with a lowercase u, so seems to build ok for me without the fix….
So it was my mistake. :-)
hehe… yep I think so :-)

BTW, I downloaded a zip file of your project from github but the flickrfetcher helper files were missing. I tried dragging my local copies into the project but I can't seem to get it to work. Any ideas? I'm just curious.
Should be there … https://github.com/i4-apps/Top-Places/tree/master/FlickrFetcher
My source code for this assignment is available here. Hopefully it will help :-)

Hi! Thanks for sharing your work! It's so helpful.
One question, in Task 10 and Hint 5, Prof. Hegarty mentioned that id is a unique identifier of photos. So I got the impression that he wanted us to store id's in NSUserDefaults, instead of photos (NSDictionaries). I stored photos, because I don't know how we can find the photo with the id. I think you did the same thing. But do you have any idea how we can store id's?
Thanks in advance:)
Hi Emma - I am storing ids in NSUserDefaults. It is the "id" field in the Dictionary.

Hi David I have used some of your code.. my app works fine and shows photo list. When it segues to photo viewController, it just shows title but image is not getting displayed.. Can you suggest wat could be wrong?
Thanks, Pal

Hi, it has been a long time since you posted this. You must have figured out the problem :) I also couldn't get the subtitles displayed at first by using the key "description._content." Later, I find out that "description is also a kind of dictionary, so the key "description._content" will not work but return null. Instead, [[listOfPhoto objectForKey:@"description"]objectForKey:@"_content"] will do the job

item.content:encoded: For your pleasure - Millionaire Calculator Please leave any bugs, feature requests or other feedback as a comment below.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Amazing, superb website page layout! The time have you been running a blog regarding? you create posting appear quick. The complete glimpse of your respective website is wonderful, not to the material material!

Dear David Barton, I'm Vita, from Best10Apps.com. I find ' Millionaire Calculator ' on App Store. It's a very cool Utilities. I'd love to recommend it to our website. Since 2011, 1000 + developers cooperated with us and 8800+ apps have been recommended to millions of visitors, such as: Lep's World 2 Plus ( Highest Ranks: Top 9 in Games ), GroupShot ( Highest Ranks: Top 1 Photo & Video Apps ). Our editors are preparing an editorial review for ' Millionaire Calculator '. Your app will have chance to be recommended to our Homepage. We need more info to help us understand your app better, such as unique features, promo codes or press release. When will you send me the info? Best Regards, Vita
